definitions: provide a place of refuge or shelter for someone or something
keep a thought or feeling secretly in one's mind for a long time
examples: The coastal town harbored refugees during the civil war
Several countries refused to harbor the escaped criminals
She harbored resentment against her former business partner for years
He still harbors dreams of becoming a professional musician

definitions: provide a place of refuge or shelter for someone or something
keep a thought or feeling secretly in one's mind for a long time
examples: The small port harboured fishing boats during the storm
Several nations refused to harbour suspected terrorists
She harboured suspicions about his true intentions for months
He still harbours ambitions of running for political office

definitions: become or make something firm solid or rigid through cooling drying or chemical process
make someone less sympathetic or gentle through difficult experiences
strengthen determination or attitude making it more fixed and uncompromising
examples: The cement will harden completely within twenty-four hours
Leave the chocolate to harden in the refrigerator
Years of poverty had hardened him against feeling sympathy
The war hardened even the youngest soldiers
The opposition's attacks only hardened her resolve to continue
Recent events have hardened public opinion against immigration

definitions: listen carefully or pay close attention to something being said
mention or recall something from the past especially with hark back
examples: Hark how the birds sing in the early morning
The teacher told students to hark to her instructions
The novel harks back to Victorian literary traditions
His management style harks back to an earlier era

definitions: physically injure or cause pain to a person or animal
damage the reputation good condition or success of something
examples: The explosion harmed several people standing nearby
She would never harm an innocent animal
The scandal seriously harmed his political career
These chemicals could harm the environment

definitions: bring different elements into a pleasing or consistent relationship
sing or play musical notes that combine pleasantly with a melody
make laws regulations or standards consistent across different jurisdictions
examples: The designer harmonised the colors throughout the entire house
We need to harmonise our approach with company values
The choir harmonised beautifully during the final chorus
She harmonised with the lead singer on several songs
The EU aims to harmonise tax policies across member states
Countries are working to harmonise their environmental regulations

definitions: bring different elements into a pleasing or consistent relationship
sing or play musical notes that combine pleasantly with a melody
make laws regulations or standards consistent across different jurisdictions
examples: The architect harmonized modern design with traditional elements
We must harmonize our goals with available resources
The backup singers harmonized perfectly with the lead vocalist
Can you harmonize this melody in three parts?
Nations agreed to harmonize their trade regulations
The committee works to harmonize accounting standards globally

definitions: play music on a harp stringed instrument
talk or write persistently and tediously about a particular topic
examples: She learned to harp at the conservatory
The musician harped beautifully during the wedding ceremony
He constantly harps on about his college achievements
Stop harping on the same issue every meeting

definitions: strike catch or kill with a harpoon spear especially for hunting whales or large fish
examples: The whalers harpooned the whale after hours of pursuit
Fishermen still harpoon tuna in some traditional communities

definitions: break up and level soil using a harrow agricultural implement with spikes
cause acute mental distress or torment to someone
examples: The farmer harrowed the field before planting wheat
They harrowed the ground to prepare it for seeding
The documentary's images of war harrowed viewers worldwide
She was harrowed by memories of the accident

definitions: persistently attack or raid especially in warfare or combat
persistently harass pester or worry someone with repeated requests or criticism
examples: Enemy forces harried the retreating army for days
Pirates harried merchant ships along the coast
Reporters harried the celebrity with endless questions
The boss harried employees about meeting impossible deadlines

definitions: gather crops from fields when they are ripe or ready
collect or obtain a resource benefit or product for use
examples: Farmers harvest wheat in late summer months
We harvested tomatoes from our backyard garden yesterday
Scientists harvest stem cells for medical research
The company harvests data from millions of users

definitions: chop food especially meat into small pieces for cooking
discuss something thoroughly and at length often with hash out
convert data into a fixed-size string of characters using a hash function
examples: Hash the potatoes and onions for the breakfast dish
The chef hashed leftover meat for tomorrow's special
Let's hash out the details of the contract
The committee hashed over the proposal for hours
The system hashes passwords before storing them securely
This algorithm hashes the input data efficiently

definitions: harass pester or pressure someone persistently about something
argue or quarrel repeatedly especially about trivial matters
examples: Stop hassling me about cleaning my room
Salespeople hassled customers with aggressive tactics
The neighbors hassle constantly about parking spaces
Don't hassle with him over such minor issues

definitions: move or travel hurriedly in a particular direction
cause something to happen sooner or more quickly than normal
examples: She hastened to the hospital after hearing the news
The messenger hastened back with the urgent reply
The medication may hasten recovery from the illness
Poor decisions hastened the company's financial collapse

definitions: emerge from an egg or cause an egg to break open
secretly devise or develop a plan or plot often with dubious intent
shade an area with closely drawn parallel lines in drawing or engraving
examples: The chicks will hatch in twenty-one days
The mother bird hatched five healthy babies
They hatched a plan to overthrow the government
The conspirators hatched their scheme over several months
The artist hatched the background to create depth
She carefully hatched shadows in her pencil drawing

definitions: feel intense or passionate dislike for someone or something
strongly dislike or be reluctant to do something
examples: She hates dishonesty more than any other trait
Many people hate spiders and other creepy crawlers
I hate having to wake up early on weekends
He hates being told what to do

definitions: pull or drag something with effort or force especially something heavy
transport goods or materials in a vehicle especially over long distances
examples: Fishermen hauled their nets onto the boat
She hauled the heavy suitcase up three flights
Trucks haul freight across the country every day
The company hauls construction materials to building sites

definitions: manifest as a ghost or supernatural presence in a place
persistently and disturbingly present in someone's mind causing worry
visit a place frequently or spend a lot of time there
examples: Legend says her ghost haunts the old mansion
Spirits supposedly haunt the abandoned hospital
Memories of the war still haunt him today
The mistake would haunt her for years afterward
He haunts the local bookstore every weekend
Artists haunt these cafes looking for inspiration

definitions: possess own or hold something as a belonging or attribute
experience or undergo something such as an emotion or event
cause or arrange for something to be done by someone else
eat or drink something as a meal or refreshment
examples: She has three children and two dogs
The museum has an impressive collection of paintings
We had a wonderful time at the party
He had difficulty understanding the instructions
I'll have my assistant call you tomorrow
She had her hair cut yesterday afternoon
Let's have lunch at that new restaurant
They had coffee and discussed the project

definitions: sell goods especially by calling out in public places
hunt game birds or animals using trained hawks
clear the throat noisily and bring up phlegm
examples: Vendors hawk their wares in the busy market
He hawks newspapers at the train station
Nobility would hawk for sport in medieval times
They hawk rabbits in the countryside
He hawked and spat into the gutter
The old man hawked loudly before speaking

definitions: put something at risk or expose to danger
venture to make a guess or suggestion tentatively
examples: Don't hazard your health by ignoring safety protocols
The climbers hazarded their lives in the storm
I would hazard a guess that he's about forty
She hazarded the opinion that sales would improve

definitions: bully or harass newcomers especially as initiation ritual in groups
become misty cloudy or obscured by haze
examples: Senior students hazed the freshmen during orientation week
The fraternity was banned for hazing new members
Smoke from wildfires hazed the entire valley
The windows hazed over in the humid weather

definitions: move in a specified direction or toward a particular place
be in charge of or lead an organization group or activity
form or be positioned at the top or front of something
examples: We're heading north for our summer vacation
The ship headed toward the nearest port
She heads the marketing department at the company
He headed the investigation for three years
A large statue heads the memorial monument
The parade was headed by the marching band

definitions: deliberately strike someone or something forcefully with one's head
examples: The player was sent off for headbutting an opponent
The angry ram headbutted the fence repeatedly

definitions: feature as the main story or give prominent publicity to something
appear or perform as the main attraction at an event
examples: The scandal headlined newspapers across the country
Major outlets headlined the breaking news story
The famous band will headline the music festival
She headlined comedy shows throughout her career

definitions: establish or locate the headquarters or main offices of an organization in a particular place
examples: The company is headquartered in Silicon Valley
They decided to headquarter their operations in London

definitions: restore someone to health or cure them of injury or illness
become sound or healthy again after injury or illness
repair or restore harmony in relationships or emotional wounds
examples: The doctor's treatment healed her broken bones
Time and rest will heal most minor injuries
The wound healed completely within two weeks
His ankle is healing nicely after the surgery
Counseling helped heal their troubled marriage
Only forgiveness can heal such deep emotional wounds

definitions: put or throw things in a pile carelessly or untidily
give or bestow something in large quantities or abundantly
examples: She heaped dirty clothes in the laundry basket
They heaped branches for the evening bonfire
Critics heaped praise on the young performer
The coach heaped criticism on the team's performance

definitions: perceive sounds with the ears or become aware of by sound
receive information or news about something or someone
listen to and judge a case or argument formally in court
examples: Can you hear the music from next door?
I heard someone calling my name
Have you heard about the new restaurant opening?
I heard that she got the promotion
The judge will hear the case next Tuesday
The committee heard testimony from several witnesses

definitions: make something hot or warm by applying heat energy
become hot or warm as temperature rises
become or make more intense passionate or angry emotionally
examples: Heat the soup before serving it
The sun heats the earth during daytime
The metal heats quickly when exposed to flame
The room heated up after closing the windows
The debate heated as tempers began to flare
His angry words heated the already tense situation

definitions: lift or haul something heavy with great effort
throw something heavy with force and effort
rise and fall rhythmically or spasmodically like waves or breathing
make an effort to vomit or experience nausea
examples: They heaved the boulder out of the way
Workers heaved sandbags onto the truck
She heaved the hammer as far as possible
Protesters heaved rocks at the police
The ship heaved in the stormy seas
His chest heaved with labored breathing
She felt sick and began to heave
The smell made him heave uncontrollably

definitions: talk to someone in a bullying domineering way trying to intimidate
examples: The manager hectored employees about minor mistakes constantly
Stop hectoring me about my personal choices

definitions: avoid making a definite decision statement or commitment
surround or bound with a hedge or hedges
protect oneself against financial loss by making counterbalancing transactions
examples: Politicians often hedge when asked about controversial issues
She hedged her answer to avoid offending anyone
They hedged their property with tall evergreen shrubs
The garden was hedged with boxwood plants
Investors hedge their portfolios against market downturns
The company hedged its currency exposure

definitions: pay careful attention to and take notice of advice or warning
examples: You should heed the doctor's advice about exercise
Few people heeded the storm warnings

definitions: repair or replace the heel of a shoe or boot
cause a ship or boat to lean to one side
follow closely behind someone especially a dog following its owner
examples: The cobbler heeled my favorite boots yesterday
These shoes need to be heeled and soled
Strong winds caused the yacht to heel sharply
The sailboat heeled over in the strong breeze
The obedient dog heeled beside its owner
She trained her puppy to heel on command

definitions: lift or carry something heavy to test or feel its weight
carry or haul something heavy with effort
examples: She hefted the package to estimate shipping costs
He hefted the sword to test its balance
Workers hefted heavy equipment up the stairs
They hefted grain sacks onto the truck

definitions: make something physically higher or taller in position
make or become more intense acute or prominent
examples: They heightened the fence for better security
The platform was heightened by six inches
The crisis heightened tensions between the countries
Music heightens the emotional impact of films

definitions: steal something in a robbery especially from an institution
examples: Thieves heisted millions from the downtown bank
The gang heisted valuable paintings from the museum

definitions: steer a ship or boat using the helm
be in charge of or direct an organization or project
examples: The captain helmed the vessel through rough waters
She learned to helm sailing boats last summer
He helmed the company during its expansion phase
She will helm the new research initiative

definitions: make it easier for someone to do something by offering assistance
improve a situation or problem make something better
serve food or drink to someone
examples: Can you help me carry these boxes upstairs?
The volunteers helped rebuild homes after the hurricane
This medicine should help your headache
Regular exercise helps reduce stress levels
Help yourself to some cake and coffee
The waiter helped us to more wine

definitions: fold and sew the edge of cloth or clothing
surround and restrict the space or movement of someone
examples: She hemmed the dress to the perfect length
I need to hem these curtains before hanging them
Enemy forces hemmed in the troops
Tall buildings hemmed the narrow street

definitions: suffer or cause heavy uncontrolled bleeding from blood vessels
lose or drain away rapidly and in large amounts
examples: The patient began to hemorrhage after surgery
The wound hemorrhaged profusely before treatment
The company hemorrhaged money during the recession
The political party hemorrhaged support after the scandal

definitions: dye or color hair or skin using henna plant extract
examples: She hennaed her hair a rich auburn color
The bride's hands were hennaed with intricate patterns

definitions: announce or publicize something especially with fanfare
be a sign that something is about to happen or begin
examples: Trumpets heralded the king's arrival at court
The press heralded her as the next great novelist
Dark clouds herald the approaching storm
These changes herald a new era in technology

definitions: move together as a group or crowd in one direction
gather and guide a group of animals or people somewhere
examples: Cattle herded together during the thunderstorm
Tourists herded into the museum entrance
Cowboys herded the cattle across the plains
Teachers herded students into the auditorium

definitions: pause before saying or doing something due to uncertainty or nervousness
be reluctant or unwilling to do something
examples: She hesitated before answering the difficult question
He hesitated at the door before knocking
Don't hesitate to call if you need help
I hesitate to criticize without knowing all facts

definitions: chop or shape wood or stone with an axe or similar tool
shape or form something by cutting or chopping
conform strictly to rules principles or standards
examples: Lumberjacks hewed timber in the forest
He hewed firewood for the winter months
Sculptors hewed statues from marble blocks
They hewed steps into the rock face
The judge hewed closely to legal precedent
The company hews to traditional business practices

definitions: cast a magic spell on someone especially to cause harm or misfortune
examples: The witch supposedly hexed anyone who crossed her
Villagers believed the old woman could hex their crops

definitions: spend the winter in a dormant state as some animals do
remain inactive or indoors for an extended period
examples: Bears hibernate in caves during winter months
Many small mammals hibernate to survive cold weather
I plan to hibernate at home this weekend
He hibernated in his room studying for exams
